specs/train/approved/ceph-pg-autotune.rs.message: Do we already pass sufficient weight information from consuming charms to drive the auto-scaler?

Yeah, the piece of information we need is either "estimated size" or "estimated percentage". Our ReplicatedPool and ErasurePool classes both currently accept an expected percentage that is used to calculate the desired PGs.

The only potential problem would be if an operator has actually unset the default configuration options in the related charms, as the defaults include an expected weight (ex: https://github.com/openstack/charm-cinder-ceph/blob/master/config.yaml#L12)

I'm not sure whether v1 is the right place to enable this feature to be on by default but we could consider:

a) new deployments use auto pg scaler by default
b) charm upgrades/upgrades to nautilus for existing deployments don't

would that make sense? they new deployments get this great kool-aid and existing deployments don't get warnings

I'm nervous to try to detect new vs upgrading. My core proposal here is to enable the module (but turn off the autotuning globally) so that an admin could enable it via a charm config option. That said, I'm not sure what the easiest way to reconfigure all existing pools with the new tuning options is but that would be part of the goal.

In short, the proposal here is to not enable it, by default, in new OR existing clusters, but to make it available to either.

As a slight shift, we _could_ enable it by default once we actually are passing the expected pool percentages to it correctly. The issue with warnings comes in because the default config option in Ceph for this is "WARN".

The actual option has (both globally and per-pool) three options: on, off, and warn. The default is to warn, which ends up with ceph health showing a warning; however, if we either disable OR enable it, there shouldn't be warnings, and the pool PGs shouldn't actually change much (as we're passing the same data that we used in the initial PG placement.

I suspect that the only time enabling it by default (as long as we put the pool weights in the correct place) will only result in any change at all if more storage has been added without updating the number of PGs manually, in which case this may cause a scale out. On the plus side, Nautilus also adds improvement internally to that type of scale out, causing it to automatically only move around a maximum of 5% of the remapped PGs.

Sounds good!

A config without a default where the charm code can decide what do do might replace the need for an action, but that would be meddling with implementation detail, just a thought.

I'm happy with your line of thought here.

I think we can actually handle new vs. upgrade with regards to enabling this module or not.

If we do that, we may need an action to enable it if a user wants to enable it post-facto. Maybe it could have a new config option (default: True) to enable this feature, but the actual module only gets enabled on new cluster manager setup.

That way, we could ensure that intentional choice must be made to enable this feature on an existing cluster, while enabling it, by default, on new Nautilus+ clusters?

I would agree with James here on taking a conservative approach with regard to existing clusters.

The upstream feature is new and even though it should behave as you describe it may contain bugs and we may encounter deployments set up in a way neither we nor the upstream has anticipated when implementing the feature.

As a external weight to this, upstream is currently not enabling the feature on new Nautilus installs by default [0].


I'd vote for enable it for new deployments in "on" mode by default, and not enabling the mgr module at all on charm/ceph upgrades.

I guess the operator of a existing cluster should have choice of explicit opt-in by setting a config, and operators of new clusters should have an opt-out.

0: https://ceph.com/rados/new-in-nautilus-pg-merging-and-autotuning/

tasks/client.yaml.message: the package module should be idempotent - it should not e necessary to need the previous stat task?

Good question, Jonathan.  The reason we're checking for the lib first, is because the package `glibc` used to install the file.  It has been deprecated and removed from `glibc`, and a new package `libnsl` was added for backwards compatibility.

If the file is there, it means `glibc` includes it, and installing `libnsl` will fail because it does not exist in the distro.

If the file is not there, it means `glibc` no longer includes it, so `libnsl` needs to be installed.

I should also point out that this is a backport into stable/stein and this patch has already merged into master.

I still don't understand why do we need to include an extra step to stop the services. What was the issue with using only one tag "system_upgrade_transfer_data" ? The way this is approached will imply stopping the services twice, iiuc:

1- openstack overcloud external-upgrade run \
    --tags system_upgrade_stop_services \
    --limit ControllerOpenstack,Database,Messaging
  
 This step will stop the services for all the controllers in which the service is running and the mysql service

2- openstack overcloud external-upgrade run \
    --tags system_upgrade_transfer_data \
    --limit ControllerOpenstack,Database,Messaging

 This step will stop again all the services, as the rest of services contain both tags:
tags:
 - never
 - system_upgrade_stop_services
 - system_upgrade_transfer_data

and perform the database transfer for this service.

Why can't we have then only one tag for all the services?

tags:
 - never
 - system_upgrade_transfer_data

Is it to allow re-running the services stopping if anything went wrong?

We should have both `system_upgrade_transfer_data` and `system_upgrade_stop_services` here i think. We want to make sure that when we run the data transfer, the services will get stopped, but we don't want this to apply vice versa.

Thanks! Maybe for url_path_template_key and url_path_template_value. See next comment for a bit of a discussion.

Do we plan to enforce limits on how long a template string can be? If so, I assume that is something we're going to be doing in code?

I'm wondering how much we'll need to safe-guard against cases that might result in extreme database bloat.

I think this needs a more specific name in order to identify it as related to this particular table
++, follow the general convention when naming constraints (look at past migrations/initial state migrations)
Is this meant to be unique constrained and/or indexed?

Do *NOT* use ENUM types. If we ever have to expand it, the only solution is to migrate to a new table and expand the dataset (no-downtime upgrades/rolling upgrades -- the old app will error on the new ENUM type).

Enforce the types strictly in code/business logic and ignore rows with an invalid enum type.

Also expand on what "context" type vs "user" type is.
I might not be understanding something completely, but these last two tables seem to have a lot in common. Is there an advantage to keeping them separated?

I'm spending a large amount of time on the data model here, and I simply don't see how this is translating into code [this is a pretty dense model]. I'd like to see the code that will use this so I can understand clearly the template_key and template_value.


I get the feeling that this is over-normalizing data, but with the code this might make a lot more sense.
I'm still trying to wrap my head around this schema but my gut feeling is that if it's really this complex then it would actually be better to manage it in code and not try to model it in the DB.

They are, yes. I'm keeping them separated to avoid the awkwardness of having two foreign key constraints, one of which always needs to be null if the other is not null.

For one of these tables forms the list of allowable keys for url path templates (and thus references that table). While the other one holds templates to interpolate for interpolation into a capability (and thus references the capability table). It would be technically possible to complain them, but I'd prefer this clean separation.

Alternatively, one could turn both or either of these into JsonBlob columns, but I'm not really fond of that idea since,  being a blob, it is opaque. I'd prefer defining these lists' structure through the database schema rather than having it hidden away in the code somewhere.

hooks/lxd_utils.py.message: I wonder if there is already something like this in charm-helpers from other charms that use(d) snaps? If not I think this and other generic snap functions should live in charm-helpers.

I had a look at there wasn't really anything that worked well.  As we don't seem to be pursuing a snap strategy at the moment, I've avoided adding more to charm-helpers, and tried to keep it contained to this charm.  charm-helpers sometimes becomes a bit of a dumping ground!
Would it make sense to move pkg config prior to lxd-dummy install and other pkg purges above?

It's local config rather than package config.  the pkg_ bit is to indicate that the config location is the one that is used when the package version is active, as compared with the path that is used with snaps.
Maybe this code can be shared with charm-nova-compute?

There's a bit of tension over whether to put something in a library (charm-helpers) when two things need them.  However, I thought that as this is specific to *just* nova-compute/lxd that putting it in charm-helpers is overkill and would (probably) add the code to every other charm that doesn't need it.  i.e. where to put it, etc.
That doesn't seem right that it would take so long. Have you talked to Stephane about it?

Yes, it's variable, and depends a bit on what the kernel is doing at the time.  Sometimes it is very quick, and at others it takes 2 to 3 minutes to do the restart.  It might be an artifact of running on serverstack, etc.  It does eventually restart, so this is working around those (complex) issues.

hooks/nova_compute_utils.py.message: Fyi, there's also a snap_install_requested() function in charm-helpers.
This is doing something different.  It's testing to see where the lxc binary is; on a pkg installed disco, for example, it's actually a snap ... this is unambiguous and verifies where the lxc bin is.
Was this check meant to be different from the check in lxc_bin()?
Not particularly; I could change the former, but they both effectively do the same thing.

specs/stein/approved/lxd-snap-install.rs.message: Is think the channel selection should be optional and we should default that to "stable". What do you think?

At the moment, the default is an empty string, which defaults to the distro package.  I think this should stay as the default (i.e. default to package) rather than default to the snap, as it's only going to work with xenial and above.  It could default to the snap for xenial and above, and the package for before xenial but that might be surprising?  At present, the operator has to explicitly ask for the snap.  In existing xenial, if it defaulted to the snap for xenial and above, then an upgrade to the new charm would force an upgrade to the snap.

In the current mode of operation, nothing will change on upgrades, and choosing the appropriate snap channel is a decisive selection by the operator.

When you mean "changed away" from snap, my understanding is that it can also indicate whether package should be used? like:

  source: apt
  source: "snap:stable"

?

Could you add some examples?
Yes, perhaps the wording is not clear.  I'll add some examples.

We will have to document that somewhere. That looks to be an important upgrade impact.

Also I imagine the default will be to continue using packages until operators decide to tweak the config to use snap and that until a phase of deprecation. We should probably add some clarifications.

Yes, I think it's agreed that it'll be documented in the README.  I think I'll also add a work item (below) to document it in the charm guide as well.  And if we capture it in the release notes, then that should round it out.
This is already handles in the eper spec about the rename
Hi icey, could you provide a link please?  Thanks.
It would help if I could type, the previous message was about the "peer spec" - https://review.openstack.org/#/c/635497/

Hum.. I should have indicated that in my previous comment but 'source' does not look to clearly explain the purpose of it. Basically I don't think it's a good name :-)

Also using a complex string is probably not the best choice since that one is going to be used with 'snap:something' only, no 'apt:something' or 'any:something' are going to be added.

My suggestion would be to use a boolean that to indicate whether we want to use snap and a string to indicate the channel, so we can specify a default one.

  snap_enabled = True/False
  snap_channel = 'stable'
I see, thank you.

As Chris mentions in his reply, unfortunately, this ship has sailed.  Every charm uses the a single string to indicate an "alternative to distro" installation source, and the charms that are snap enabled (e.g. keystone) use "snap:<channel>" to indicate a snap source.  Doing something different now would be surprising for operators.  It's bad enough that it's "source" rather than "openstack-origin", but that ship has sailed too.

This is an existing configuration option, and is consistent across the OpenStack charms: in the OpenStack specific charms, it's generally openstack-origin, and in non OpenStack ones (ceph, percona), it's source
I didn't cross check source usage for snaps, but I just want to make sure it aligns with existing charms that use snaps (I think keystone via openstack-origin).
It seems to be how it's used.  I looked at keystone and it uses snap_install_requested() from charm-helpers which looks for "snap:" and then splits off the remainder as the channel.
So if we use the options suggested, we don't need of this paragraph :)
What would be the behavior if operators change the channel used?

In it's current form it will be possible to change the 'source' config value and the charm will evaluate what it currently is on and whether it can do something with it.  At present, if it's already snap:<something> then changed source to snap:<new> will do a snap refresh lxd --channel=<new>.  Also pkg -> snap, but not snap -> package.  Whether the snap refresh succeeds is down to the lxd snap package.  e.g. edge -> stable probably wouldn't work, but stable -> edge would.  It's not that different to changing openstack-origin on most of the other charms.
OK Thanks, so basically it's not possible to upgrade lxd from stable to edge using 'source' option (or the opposite). Can you add note about that point?
The charm will enter a blocked state to indicate that it can't continue with the change; the underlying LXD payload will stay the same (and continue running).

That is really not good :/ I also think network connectivity will be lost since based on the script a new bridge will be created/used.

Is that possible instead of "forcing usage of the script" we have an action which the operators will have to use against the containers to migrate them one by one? (and why not and option like '--all')
ACK

Unfortunately, that's not how LXD is written.  The singular lxd.migrate is all that's provided, and it provides everything  In reality, LXD hasn't been written to be installed with BOTH packaged and snapped versions at the same time.  The lxd.migrate is provided to switch to the snapped version which is the future.

Other charms do offer an "managed upgrade", but this isn't offered on this charm at present, as "source" has traditionally been an 'install only' option.

It could be pulled from the config-changed hook (i.e. made install only), but the additional flexibility was to allow a migration from packages.  Anything further is probably outside the scope of this spec.

Minor simplification potential:

  tenant.report_build_page = conf.get('report-build-page', False)

Then you can avoid the if. However the if check is what is used for everything here so probably better to rewrite the whole lot if we decide that reads better.

That does make it slightly less future-proof, since when the implicit default is later changed in the Tenant class this would need updating too. As it is now, only the initial state of the classvar needs to be changed to change the default (which I gather is a planned future state).

    tenant.report_build_page = conf.get('report-build-page', tenant.report_build_page)

it is more correct:
Exchange is an AMQP mechanism design to dispatch the messages like a proxy.
The messages are always published to exchanges. Exchanges then distribute message copies to queues using rules called bindings.

AMQP protocol defines different types of exchanges:
 - direct
 - topic
 - fanout
 - headers

See here https://www.rabbitmq.com/tutorials/amqp-concepts.html#exchanges for more detail

I'd say:
AMQP exchange can work without any binding. By default, no exception is raised if the message is not redirected to any queue. 

With mandatory flag RabbitMQ rasies a callback if the message is not routed to any queue.

The AMQP queue is the messages store, it can store the messages in memory or persist the messages to the disk.

The queue is bound to the exchange through one or more bindings.

Consumers can consume messages from the queue.

see here: https://www.rabbitmq.com/tutorials/amqp-concepts.html#queues for more detail.

the key is part of the AMQP envelop and not headers, see for example: https://www.rabbitmq.com/releases/rabbitmq-java-client/v2.4.1/rabbitmq-java-client-javadoc-2.4.1/index.html?com/rabbitmq/client/Envelope.html
Why only V3.8? actually, oslo can work also with other versions.
AMQP 0-9-1
AMQP 0-9-1 (Advanced Message Queuing Protocol) is an open application layer that allows clients applications to communicate with messaging middleware brokers in a standard way.

On the other hand, I am not sure the django application project should be responsible for sample configurations of all WSGI web servers. We are not necessarily familiar with all web servers, so such configuration samples can be out of date easily.

In fact, this wsgi file is a pure python script which can be executed directly from the command line by any process.

With the shebang we make it fully universal for any kind of web servers, even exotic ones.

This wgsi file is intended for all web servers and not only apache.

In fact, the make_web_conf command should add support for --nginx, --uwsgi, etc (and grow).

The reason we have the shebang is to insure this script is universal whatever web server uses it.
It can only help but can't harm.
It also helps any one reading it to know which python executable is used and can greatly help when debugging on a server with multiple python versions (I've seen some...).

is better. getattr default value should match the default value.

oslo_messaging/_drivers/impl_rabbit.py.message: Nit: This violates our import grouping recommendations. My comments below might make it kind of a moot point as they would add a bunch of logic here that makes the recommendation somewhat meaningless.

How often do we create new connections? I'm wondering if we should factor out this code and run it once at import. None of these conditions can change at runtime anyway, and then we don't have potential issues with running a bunch of import code every time we create a connection.

Since we don't currently use the global conf object here, maybe we just factor out the import code and only leave the conf check and the module overwrite. Basically, above when we import threading, we also try the eventlet import, check for thread being patched, and then save off the original module to something like stdlib_threading.

Then at connection create time the only thing we have to do is 

if self.heartbeat_in_pthread:
    global threading
    threading = stdlib_threading

That should be significantly lower overhead than trying to import eventlet every time.

I realize this may qualify as premature optimization, but given that we've had performance issues related to imports in the past and I doubt anyone is going to do a detailed performance analysis before and after this patch, I'd rather hedge our bets. It doesn't make the code appreciably more complex.
Nit: The variable doesn't seem necessary.

If someone were to set this option in a service where eventlet isn't used, this would fail because we wouldn't have set stdlib_threading above.

So I guess I was wrong about refactoring this not making things more complicated. ;-)

I'm pretty sure this isn't true. If you pass a string with an empty line to splitlines and then strip it you get something that evaluates as False, at least in my local testing.

For example:

foo = """test
testing

after blank
"""

for line in foo.splitlines(True):
    print('--' + line if line.strip() else line, end='')
[bnemec@Carbon scripts]$ python3 ./test.py 
--test
--testing

--after blank

You can see it correctly did not prepend the indentation string to the empty line. That's the behavior we're looking for here.

If I remove the if statement then it results in:

--test
--testing
--
--after blank

Which is wrong.
